§Show NotesAPOLO’S QUESTIONS BEGIN
Why women may have a harder time fasting, and tips for those who are struggling [2:10]
Apolo’s wife

Apolo and his wife practicing fasting
Apolo can go up to 7 days pretty easily
His wife really struggles after 72 hours
At that point she basically has no energy to even leave the house
She has no ability to do anything even remotely mentally strenuous

Peter’s thoughts:

Peter has noticed that his female patients have a tougher time with fasting (and even time restricted feeding)
He’s not sure why (maybe some evolutionary reasons)

–For people who struggle, Peter progress his patients as follows:

Once someone is able to consistently do 18 hr fasts with 6 hr eating window
He then moves them to 1 meal per day
Next will be a 36 hour fast

Fasting tips from Peter:

Peter suggests checking glucose levels to get some insight into why he energy might be so low
Peter says when you feel this crappy, it’s important to not push through
You also need MORE water than you think

When you fast you excrete sodium at a higher rate 
Secondly, food has water in it so you need to compensate for that


Don’t cut caffeine for a long fast if you are a big caffeine person

 
Is there any place for fasting as part of a nutritional strategy in adolescents? [6:15]

There may be certain situations where it might make sense
Such as obese kids, T2 diabetes, NAFLD

But at the same time, one has to be very careful…

Adolescents are still growing (anabolic mode) 
There is a critical window during which deprivation of food can be potentially harmful
I’ve certainly seen a subset of people who have eating disorders during adolescence and it sort of imprinted their endocrine system in a way that’s come back to haunt them as an adult

“My view is that unless you’re an adult, really this isn’t something that should be considered as a regular part of how you eat.”
 
Tips for learning and retaining large amounts of new information (and the best nutritional approach) [9:15]

Apolo is doing an intensive MBA program at Wharton 
He is going to be consuming large amounts of information 
More importantly he needs to retain the information

What tips does Peter have?
  1 Write it down with a pen

Peter retains info MUCH better when he writes it down on paper with a pen (i.e., not typed)
He tries to condense and synthesize the information down
He personally likes paper with no lines (Apolo needs graph paper)

  2 Small groups where you can quiz each other on conceptual info

Find good study partners but only 2-4 people
Peter is particular about his pens (he likes fountain pens, fine liners, certain types of roller balls, and different colors)

  3 Sleep is crucial for retaining info (so time management is key)

Hippocampus is sensitive to sleep deprivation
Cramming might help on a test, but for long-term consolidation of memories you need sleep

What is your preferred diet for consuming large amounts of information? 

Simple answer: Anything that is going to minimize swings in glucose
Is fasting helpful?

Peter says it’s unclear
The literature about fasting and cognitive performance is not that great
However, there is tons of anecdotal stuff (e.g., more mental clarity)
Peter personally has felt remarkably sharp while in ketosis


Exogenous ketones

Peter says taking a ketone ester could help (as it seems to have helped him in the past)
Peter suggests that as something Apolo could try out



In summary:
“If I were in that situation, I don’t think I would fast during that window necessarily. I’d probably do some time restriction and eat a really clean diet that, even if it wasn’t fully ketogenic, it would probably be relatively low carb.”
 
Must read books of 2019 [14:45]
Am I Being Too Subtle?: Straight Talk From a Business Rebel by Sam Zell
Lifespan: Why We Age―and Why We Don’t Have To by David Sinclair
Infinite Jest by David Foster Wallace
 
If you could only keep a few watches for the rest of your life which would they be? [16:45]
Peter’s picks:

Speedmaster Omega 321
Rolex Daytona

Either the 6263 “non Newman”
Or the 6240 “non Newman”


Probably a Richard Mille watch… one of these:

11-03
50-03 (“McLaren”)
53-01


Athletes you have an RM watch:

Odell Beckham Jr.
Rafael Nadal
Bubba Watson 



Apolo’s picks:

Patek Nautilus
An “anniversary” Rolex
Richard Mille watch 

 
What workout would Peter do inside a hotel room? [22:15]
First, would make sure to have a stability exercise 

Dynamic neuromuscular stabilization (DNS) exercises
On your back, or front, or side working on core activation
Intra abdominal pressure (IAP)
“Symmetric cylindrical activation”
There’s a whole bunch of exercises there, but Peter makes a hybrid one of those

Secondly, a single leg lunge

So the single leg step back (or step up) lunge
Or perhaps a single leg “get up” off a low surface

Finally, he’d to handstand push ups 

Put legs up on a wall, but not in a “full stand” position (you don’t need to be under that much stress)
Peter’s doing this as a scapular exercise (good way to train serratus strength and shoulder stabilizers)

 
What is Peter’s ultimate gorge meal? [23:45]

Peter loves sushi but would find that hard to “gorge” on 
Probably would be a multiple-course italian meal

E.g., salad, pasta, meat dish, gelato


Curry stir fry

“I can seem to eat it in infinite volumes probably because it feels so healthy.”

Check out AMA #5 for the complete recipe



 
How do you foresee fasting as a mechanism for performance in athletes? [25:30]
Apolo wants to know specifically how fasting might be used in the following manners:

For manipulating testosterone levels
For injury recovery/regeneration

Peter’s thoughts on manipulation testosterone:

In Peter’s experience, his testosterone levels plummets after a 7 day fast
95+% percent of the population exists between 5 and 25
After a fast, Peter is at 4
He would need to do daily checks to see if there’s a pulse spike that you could exploit
But even if there was… the question is, would it be clinically significant? 
Peter thinks testosterone levels have a bigger impact with training (and recovery and growth) versus how much it would matter on the day of a race (outside of very extreme levels)
In summary, he would need to see something more compelling before believing that you could manipulate testosterone spikes to enhance performance in a clinically significant way

Peter’s thoughts on testosterone for recovery and inflammation:

The literature on inflammation and fasting clearly shows a reduction in inflammation 
Additionally, everybody almost without exception notices that little aches and pains just vanish
Is that the autophagy we’re experiencing? .. “Possibly.”
So Peter sees fasting as a powerful tool for an athlete (Not unlike the way you probably use an ice bath)

⇒ Now the question is how do you incorporate it with volume of training? 

When fasting, Peter notices that i) his top end endurance is lower and ii) he needs more recovery time in between sets and iii) it hurts a lot more to really push himself during those fasts
Does Apolo think he could have incorporated fasting into his training in his Olympic days?

He thinks he could have… he’d probably have done it like so:

Do one fast in the preseason
Do one or two during the season
And do one immediately post-season




“From an injury prevention and injury recovery lense, I think that would’ve helped immensely.”

Many Olympians are reluctant to use fasting because they don’t want to mess up their training

Peter thinks most athletes are over-training in volume and intensity and under training and specificity
But if people start to realize you don’t need that much volume with better neuromuscular training and less actual stress, you could achieve the same benefits and therefore you might actually be able to go through better periods of fasting

An alternative strategy for athletes: Hypocaloric feeding with creatine supplementation

Hypocaloric feeding is where you’re eating 750 to a 1,000 calories per day
You still could get enough glycogen replacement which is good because that’s probably where the athletes are hurt the most with a water-only fast combined with training volume
Additionally, Peter would overcompensate with creatine


If a normal creatine cycle is 5 grams per day, you do 10 grams per day 
So if you’re keeping creatine stores full and getting 100 grams of carbohydrates a day…
That might be able to ward off a lot of the sort of extreme performance deterioration
While still getting the benefits of the injury restoration or healing

 
What is driving Peter to strive for excellence? [33:30]
Apolo wants to know what drives Peter do work so hard, to get out of bed in the morning, and to strive for excellence:

Paradoxically, Peter considers himself a very lazy person innately
And this is a tough question because sometimes you don’t really know what’s driving you
Perhaps you’re just doing something because you’ve always done it and you don’t know the alternative
One hypothesis Peter has about himself is that he might be striving so hard because he’s worried about the alternative which is hin innately lazy personality might take over so he’s sort of overcompensating 

A love for learning and for teaching:
“I am obsessed with knowing stuff. There’s just no denying it.”

Anytime Peter reads something or is asked a question he doesn’t know the answer to… it is really hard for him to let it go
Not that this personality trait is great… it’s neither good nor bad, “it just is”
And so there is probably a whole bunch of neurotransmitters that are involved in the satisfaction he gets from learning something new ⇒ some amount of dopamine that’s making him feel better

Teaching:  he also enjoys teaching but he doesn’t necessarily know why
Peter strongly relates to a book by Richard Feynman called The Pleasure of Finding Things Out

§
SASHA’S QUESTIONS BEGIN
What are you most excited about in the longevity space? [38:45]
Anything that involves mTOR
–Why?

The mechanistic target of rapamycin is a very potent nutrient sensing protein aggregate within cells 
and like all things in biology too much and too little of it can be a bad thing
But one thing that seems really clear is at least transient inhibition of this nutrient sensing machinery seems to produce a really impressive longevity phenotype

–Rapamycin

The easiest way to demonstrate the longevity benefits of inhibiting mTOR is with the drug called rapamycin
In 2009, the first study unequivocally showed the power of this drug rapamycin in treating normal mice was published
They were given rapamycin to mice late enough in life that normally you wouldn’t see much of an effect with other types of interventions
That effect has been demonstrated repeatedly across multiple strains of other mice and all sorts of different animals

–Other ways to target mTOR: 

Fasting is another way to transiently turn down mTOR
And more drugs are in development for mTOR inhibition

–In summary: Peter calls it “the most important target of a longevity strategy”
Do Peter take rapamycin himself?

Yes, for about a year
Peter, however, doesn’t see anything noticeably improving in his blood work
Many patients on the other hand see huge improvements such as…

Lipids get better
Their triglycerides go down
Their glycemic stuff gets better


Dosing:

Must be taken intermittently (Peter takes it once per week)
Doing it daily doesn’t have the same positive benefits and comes with more negative side effects



–Peter on why he doesn’t see the same list of benefits in his own blood work:

“I suspect that people who are metabolically well enough and I probably fit into that category, the benefits it’s having are well beneath the surface of things that we can measure with our current toolkit, which is pretty limited.”

 
At what point do you see enough data or proof that a new drug, or type of fasting is worth trying it out for yourself? [41:30]
The few things that Peter wants to see:
–First, really convincing animal data

Across enough animals that it’s not easy to chalk up as just sort of an artifact of one particular species

–Secondly, some sort of human clinical evidence of the manifestation

One end of the spectrum might be…

Humans that have a genetic mutation that does something similar to the effect of this intervention have this sort of phenotype and that’s favorable 


On the other end of the spectrum…

It could be humans who take a drug for a different reason but have changes in a different area which are intriguing 
So for example, an SGLT2 inhibitor is used to treat and lower blood sugar in patients with type 2 diabetes but maybe you can see what that drug is doing with respect to this other thing that’s sort of interesting



–Thirdly, you’d like to really understand the mechanistic reason this effect is happening
–Final principle: Can I bracket my risk?

If you can identify the range of risk and make sure it’s not too high where the benefit may be significant than you can feel better about doing it
Example, fasting… “with fasting, I don’t think we’re ever going to see a study that will demonstrate the benefits of in terms of longevity of long-term periodic fasting, it’s just too hard to do. . .But again, the risks of these things are incredibly low and we have so much biologic basis to fall back on that I feel more confident doing it. Other things, however, I’d want to see a bit more data before I would sort of decide, oh yeah, well that’s definitely worth doing.”

And how do you ensure you aren’t conflating variables?

It’s very hard, says Peter
He will try to reduce confounders when doing self experimenting by making sure the conditions are consistent

We need better assays to measure nuanced cellular responses to drugs

To really get insights into longevity benefits, we need better testings

“I really wish we would spend a lot more time and resources developing the types of assays that could measure the more nuanced cellular responses of these types of drugs. 
We already have amazingly potent treatments (fasting, exercise, metformin, rapamycin, etc.)
What we don’t have is tools to really measure how well they work on healthy people in terms of producing longevity
Why don’t we?

The diagnostics business is a really bad business to be in
It would require creating a new business model. 
The business works around creating molecules, not creating tests to measure things like what fasting protocol is best, for example



“The deeper I get into the science of longevity, the more I am absolutely convinced that nutrition and exercise … are such incredible drugs. They’re so ubiquitous. Like you can do them so often, you can spread that dose across so much.”
 
Is it possible to obsess so much about your health that it becomes a negative stressor? [46:45]
How do people find the happy medium where they are not stressing about their health but also not being totally negligent?
–Warren Buffet is an example of someone who seems supremely happy emotionally despite apparently eating McDonalds daily and probably not exercising
—Is it possible that if Buffet ate well and took care of himself, he could be even healthier and more robust? Maybe. 
—Is it possible that if he spent time stressing about how healthy he was, he’d be less healthy? It’s possible because certainly one can go too far.
“One can absolutely spend too much time obsessing over this stuff [to the point where it becomes an added stressor in their life]”
 
Which tests are worth doing if you want to be proactive about your health? [48:15]
Peter is not particularly interested in measuring things for which he can’t do anything about it
–Example of something he IS interested in: 

There are a handful of genes that pose a risk for disease later in life that I know can’t be changed
But to know your APOE genotype is in fact useful
You can’t change it, but you can get insight into your risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease (AD)
And there are certain things you can do to reduce your risk and/or delay the possible onset of AD
Exercise plays an incredible role in: 

maintaining hippocampal volume
maintaining blood flow to the brain
controlling metabolic circulating factors that play an important role in the preservation of cognition (like in this paper, and this paper)


“So my view is, by knowing that I’m much more empowered to do something about it.” 

–Conversely. . .

Peter’s not a huge fan of doing mass sequencing of the gut biome because “I don’t know what to do with the information”

“I think one just has to know in advance before you do a test…’What are the possible outcomes here and how will that affect what I do?’ . . .If you can’t answer that question, I think you’d probably better off not doing the test.”
Which tests would Peter recommend for someone wanting to be proactive about their health?
  1 Lp(a) levels

Somewhere between 1-8 and 1-12 people have elevated Lp(a)
It’s the leading cause of inherited risk for cardiovascular disease

  2 APOE test

To know that you’re in a higher risk version I think should motivate you to work that much harder
That said, even the lowest risk category doesn’t mean you won’t get it
See Peter’s podcast with Richard Isaacson for more on APOE

*A note about cancer screening with a liquid biopsy

Only about a year away from liquid biopsies really becoming commercially viable which is a blood test where it’s going to look for circulating DNA or RNA
It will tell you if you have circulating cancer cells including the cell of origin
So this comes with some responsibility:

Imagine you’ve got a blood test and it came back and said you’ve got circulating breast cancer cells, 
but your mammogram is normal with no lump in your breast
What do you do with that information?








Would you be able to do molecular imaging?










Would you be able to start targeted therapies?

Or would it just create a sense of stress and anxiety while you sit there and wait for the next year or two for something to show up on an x ray or a physical exam?





How Peter would like to see the future in terms of these types of tests:

Rather than a bunch of standalone tests…
There will be a bunch of stacking tests that will allow us to compensate for false positives and false negatives
And be coupled also with a very aggressive front line of treatments in the presence of things that are positive

One other important measurement: Continuous Glucose Monitoring

Peter would put a continuous glucose monitor on everybody for at least three months
It would be incredibly instructive for people to walk around and understand how their glucose levels change with respect to what they eat, how poorly they sleep, when they sleep poorly, and how much their cortisol levels go up, etc.
For Peter, he sees his glucose spike with stress
How does that change his behavior?

It informs him the need for meditation



“That is part of my motivation for learning to detach myself from my thoughts when my thoughts become troubling.”
 
Are there any supplements Peter things are beneficial to be taking? [55:15]

Peter says about 80% of the population is probably very deficient in EPA and DHA
These are two very important omega-3 fatty acids that we get from fish
So there are certainly some people who eat enough fish that they don’t need to supplement that.
Data are reasonably compelling that having high levels of EPA and DHA in your tissue membranes is beneficial when supplemented to the right level

 
How does Peter’s training differ when optimizing for performance versus longevity? [56:30]
Peter says optimizing for longevity (i.e., being a kickass 90-year-old) compared to being the best at something (i.e., performance) changes how he does things
⇒ Using bench pressing as an example:

If one decided they wanted to maximize the weight they could bench, it probably puts them at undue risk
Not only potentially dropping the bar on themselves
But also in terms of how you have to position your serratus, your lats, your hips . . . it puts a bit of undue stress on the body 
And if you’re goal is to extend healthspan, it’s probably not worth the effort/risk

–How Peter does pressing:

It’s optimized around stability and long-term strength and pliability and very little to do with how much weight he’s moving
He does single arm isolated floor presses 
He uses a bamboo pole with big springy rubber things on the end and it’s hanging kettlebells off it
Maybe a total of 80 to 90 pounds
Given how unstable it is and how much it’s bouncing, it’s a far better exercise because

i) it’s not putting a fraction of the stress on my joints 
ii) And it’s forcing stabilizing muscles to do their work



 
How does taking testosterone and growth hormone affect performance versus longevity? [59:15]
Testosterone

Most hormones (e.g., cortisol, thyroid hormone) exist mostly in a U-shaped relationship, but testosterone doesn’t. 
Testosterone is in some ways the easiest drug to give somebody because more is always better in terms of performance
You can’t have too much testosterone in your body if your goal is to do anything that requires strength or speed 
And truthfully, despite all of the fear mongering around drugs, testosterone is a staggeringly safe drug
Peter has seen athletes who have 10 times the normal level of testosterone floating around in their body and it absolutely helps them perform better, “but I don’t think it’s helping them live one day longer and frankly at that level it’s probably counterproductive”

Growth hormone

I view growth hormone as a much more frightening drug than testosterone. 
And while I think growth hormone in the short term probably has enormous performance benefits…
…I’m not convinced growth hormone has any role in the treatment of longevity
It might be “anti-aging” in terms of how you look and feel, but it probably comes with a bit more risk than we want (except for a subset of patients who have really low growth hormone to begin with)

“Growth hormone is probably a great example of how it’s almost always going to improve your performance, I just don’t think of it as a great tool for longevity.”
